questions.question: A sole proprietorship is characterized by:

options.B: Unlimited personal liability for all business debts

questions.explanation: A sole proprietorship has unlimited liability—the owner is personally responsible for all business debts. Formation requires no state filing (though licenses may be needed). There is only one owner by definition.
questions.tip: Sole proprietorship: Simplest form, no filing, unlimited liability. Owner = business.

questions.question: A general partnership can be formed:

options.A: Only by filing articles with the state
options.B: By oral or written agreement, or by conduct
options.D: Only if registered with the SEC

questions.explanation: General partnerships can be formed by agreement (oral or written) or simply by conduct that demonstrates an intent to carry on a business for profit as co-owners. No state filing is required to form a general partnership.
questions.tip: General partnership: No filing needed. Can be oral, written, or implied from conduct.

questions.question: Shareholders of a corporation are generally liable for corporate debts:

options.A: Up to the amount of their investment
options.B: Personally and without limit
options.D: For debts incurred during their ownership

questions.explanation: Shareholders have limited liability—they can lose only their investment in the corporation. Personal assets are generally protected from corporate creditors. Exceptions include piercing the corporate veil and personal guarantees.
questions.tip: Corporate shareholders: Limited liability. Maximum loss = investment. Personal assets protected.

questions.question: A Limited Liability Company (LLC) provides its members with:

options.A: Only limited liability but no tax flexibility
options.B: Limited liability and choice of tax treatment

questions.explanation: LLCs combine limited liability (like corporations) with tax flexibility. By default, single-member LLCs are taxed as sole proprietorships and multi-member LLCs as partnerships, but they can elect corporate taxation.
questions.tip: LLC: Best of both worlds. Limited liability + tax flexibility (pass-through or elect corporate).

questions.question: A limited partnership must have at least:

options.B: One general partner and one limited partner

questions.explanation: A limited partnership requires at least one general partner (with unlimited liability and management authority) and at least one limited partner (with limited liability but no management authority). State filing is required.
questions.tip: LP: Must have 1+ general partner + 1+ limited partner. General = liability + control.

questions.question: The document filed with the state to form a corporation is called:

options.B: Operating agreement
options.C: Articles of incorporation (or certificate of incorporation)

questions.explanation: Articles of incorporation (also called certificate of incorporation or charter) is the document filed with the state to create a corporation. Bylaws are internal rules adopted by the corporation after formation.
questions.tip: Articles of incorporation = filed with state to form corp. Bylaws = internal rules (not filed).

questions.question: In a general partnership, each partner is:

options.A: Liable only for their share of partnership debts
options.B: Jointly and severally liable for all partnership obligations
options.C: Liable only for debts they personally incur

questions.explanation: General partners have joint and several liability for all partnership obligations. A creditor can pursue any partner for the full amount of the debt. Partners can seek contribution from other partners afterward.
questions.tip: General partners: Joint and several liability. Creditor can collect entire debt from any partner.

questions.question: Courts may 'pierce the corporate veil' and hold shareholders personally liable when:

options.B: Shareholders have commingled personal and corporate funds or used the corporation to perpetrate fraud
options.D: The corporation has more than 100 shareholders

questions.explanation: Courts pierce the veil when shareholders disregard the corporate form: commingling funds, inadequate capitalization, ignoring formalities, using the corporation as an alter ego, or committing fraud. This removes limited liability protection.
questions.tip: Veil pierced: Commingling, undercapitalization, ignore formalities, fraud. Treat corp as separate!

questions.question: Corporate directors owe the corporation duties of:

options.B: Only profit maximization

questions.explanation: Directors owe fiduciary duties of care (make informed decisions) and loyalty (act in corporation's best interest, avoid conflicts). They are not guarantors of success. The business judgment rule protects good-faith decisions.
questions.tip: Directors: Duty of care + duty of loyalty. Business judgment rule protects good-faith decisions.

questions.question: The business judgment rule protects directors from liability when:

options.B: Decisions are made in good faith, with care, and without conflicts of interest

questions.explanation: The business judgment rule presumes directors acted on an informed basis, in good faith, and in honest belief that the action was in the corporation's best interest. Directors with conflicts or who act without due diligence lose this protection.
questions.tip: BJR: Protects informed, good-faith, loyal decisions. Lost if self-dealing or grossly uninformed.

questions.question: An LLC's operating agreement:

options.A: Must be filed with the state
options.B: Governs the internal affairs of the LLC and relations among members
options.C: Is required only for single-member LLCs

questions.explanation: The operating agreement governs LLC internal affairs, member relations, management, and profit sharing. It is not filed with the state and can be oral or written (though written is advisable). It can modify most default statutory rules.
questions.tip: Operating agreement: Internal LLC rules. Not filed. Can override most default rules.

questions.question: In a general partnership, each partner has apparent authority to:

options.B: Bind the partnership in the ordinary course of business

questions.explanation: Each general partner is an agent of the partnership with apparent authority to bind it in the ordinary course of business. Actions outside ordinary course (selling real property, admitting partners, confessing judgment) require consent of all partners.
questions.tip: Partners bind partnership in ordinary course. Extraordinary acts need all partners' consent.

questions.question: Under modern law (ULPA 2001), a limited partner's liability is:

options.B: Limited to their capital contribution, regardless of participation in management
options.C: Unlimited if they vote on partnership matters
options.D: The same as a general partner

questions.explanation: Under ULPA 2001, limited partners have limited liability regardless of participation in control. The old 'control rule' that imposed liability for participating in management has been eliminated in modern limited partnership law.
questions.tip: Modern LP law: Limited partners protected even if they participate in management.

questions.question: Shareholders in a corporation generally have the right to:

options.B: Vote on major matters, elect directors, and inspect corporate records

questions.explanation: Shareholders vote on fundamental matters (mergers, amendments, dissolution), elect/remove directors, and have inspection rights. Day-to-day management is delegated to directors and officers, not shareholders.
questions.tip: Shareholders vote, elect directors, inspect. Don't manage day-to-day. That's for officers.

questions.question: A Limited Liability Partnership (LLP) provides partners with:

options.B: Protection from liability for other partners' malpractice or negligence

questions.explanation: An LLP is a general partnership where partners have limited liability for partnership obligations arising from other partners' negligence or misconduct. Partners remain liable for their own misconduct and, in some states, for contract debts.
questions.tip: LLP: Shield from other partners' malpractice. Common for law/accounting firms.

questions.question: Preferred stock typically differs from common stock by:

options.B: Having dividend and liquidation preferences but often no voting rights

questions.explanation: Preferred stock has priority over common stock for dividends and liquidation distributions. However, preferred stockholders typically don't have voting rights unless dividends are in arrears. Common stock has voting rights and unlimited upside.
questions.tip: Preferred: Dividend/liquidation priority, usually no vote. Common: Vote + unlimited upside.

questions.question: When a partner dissociates from a partnership, the partnership:

options.B: May continue or dissolve depending on the partnership agreement and circumstances

questions.explanation: Under RUPA, dissociation doesn't automatically dissolve the partnership. The partnership may continue with remaining partners buying out the dissociating partner's interest. Dissolution occurs only in certain circumstances or if partners choose.
questions.tip: Dissociation ≠ automatic dissolution. Partnership can continue; buyout departing partner.

questions.question: A shareholder derivative suit is brought by shareholders:

options.B: On behalf of the corporation against wrongdoers when the corporation fails to act

questions.explanation: A derivative suit is brought by shareholders on behalf of the corporation when directors fail to take action against wrongdoers (usually directors or officers). Recovery goes to the corporation, not directly to shareholders.
questions.tip: Derivative suit: Shareholders sue on corporation's behalf. Recovery goes to corp, not shareholders.

questions.question: An LLC can be managed by:

options.B: Only non-member managers
options.C: Members, managers, or a combination as specified in the operating agreement
options.D: A board of directors required by law

questions.explanation: LLCs can be member-managed (all members participate in management) or manager-managed (designated managers run operations). The operating agreement specifies the management structure. Managers can be members or outsiders.
questions.tip: LLC: Member-managed or manager-managed. Operating agreement controls structure.

questions.question: Preemptive rights give shareholders the right to:

options.A: Sell their shares before other shareholders
options.B: Purchase newly issued shares proportionally to maintain ownership percentage
options.C: Force the corporation to buy back their shares

questions.explanation: Preemptive rights allow existing shareholders to purchase a proportionate amount of newly issued stock before it's offered to others, maintaining their ownership percentage. These rights may be granted or denied in the articles of incorporation.
questions.tip: Preemptive rights: Buy new shares first to maintain percentage ownership. Not automatic in all states.

questions.question: A new partner admitted to an existing partnership is liable for pre-existing debts:

options.B: Only to the extent of their capital contribution to the partnership
options.C: Only for debts incurred after admission
options.D: For all debts including those before and after admission equally

questions.explanation: A new partner's liability for pre-existing partnership obligations is limited to their capital contribution. They have no personal liability for debts incurred before joining. For post-admission debts, they have full liability.
questions.tip: New partner: Pre-admission debts limited to capital. Post-admission debts = full liability.

questions.question: For shareholders to take valid action at a meeting, there must generally be:

options.B: A quorum (typically a majority of shares) present, and majority of quorum must approve
options.C: The board of directors' prior approval

questions.explanation: Shareholder action requires a quorum (usually a majority of shares entitled to vote). Once a quorum exists, a majority of shares present and voting can approve routine matters. Some actions require supermajority votes.
questions.tip: Shareholder voting: Quorum required (usually majority). Then majority of quorum approves.

questions.question: In a Limited Liability Limited Partnership (LLLP):

options.B: General partners are also protected from vicarious liability like limited partners
options.C: Only limited partners have liability protection
options.D: The entity is taxed as a corporation

questions.explanation: An LLLP combines a limited partnership with LLP status, giving general partners the same liability shield as limited partners. General partners manage but aren't personally liable for other partners' malpractice or partnership debts.
questions.tip: LLLP: LP + LLP protection. General partners get liability shield too.

questions.question: Under modern corporate law, the ultra vires doctrine (acts beyond corporate power):

options.A: Makes all unauthorized corporate acts void
options.B: Is largely abolished; corporations have broad powers unless articles limit them
options.D: Allows any shareholder to void any contract

questions.explanation: Modern corporate statutes (like MBCA) give corporations broad powers to engage in any lawful business. Ultra vires is largely abolished. It may be raised only by: shareholders to enjoin, corporation against officers, or attorney general.
questions.tip: Ultra vires mostly abolished. Corps have broad powers. Can only be raised in limited ways now.

questions.question: A de facto corporation exists when:

options.B: There is a good faith attempt to incorporate and business is conducted as a corporation

questions.explanation: A de facto corporation exists when: (1) statute exists for incorporation, (2) good faith attempt to comply, and (3) business conducted as corporation. This protects parties dealing with the entity, but the state can challenge corporate status.
questions.tip: De facto corp: Tried to incorporate in good faith + acted as corp. Protected from third parties.

questions.question: Property acquired with partnership funds is presumed to be:

options.A: Owned by the partner who acquired it
options.B: Partnership property
options.C: Personal property of all partners equally
options.D: Subject to each partner's personal creditors

questions.explanation: Under RUPA, property acquired with partnership funds is partnership property. The partnership owns property as an entity, and partners have no individual ownership interest that can be transferred or reached by personal creditors.
questions.tip: Property bought with partnership funds = partnership property. Partners can't individually transfer.

questions.question: A promoter who signs a contract on behalf of a corporation to be formed is:

options.B: Personally liable unless released by novation after incorporation
options.C: Liable only if the corporation is never formed
options.D: Automatically released when the corporation is formed

questions.explanation: Promoters are personally liable on pre-incorporation contracts. Formation and adoption by the corporation does not automatically release the promoter. Release requires novation—a new agreement where the third party releases the promoter.
questions.tip: Promoter personally liable. Incorporation + adoption doesn't release. Need novation!

questions.question: A creditor with a judgment against an LLC member can obtain a charging order that:

options.A: Allows the creditor to take the member's LLC interest
options.B: Gives the creditor the right to receive distributions that would go to the member

questions.explanation: A charging order is the exclusive remedy against a member's LLC interest. It gives the creditor rights to receive distributions that would otherwise go to the debtor-member. It doesn't give management rights or ability to force liquidation.
questions.tip: Charging order: Creditor gets distributions only. Can't take interest, vote, or force dissolution.

questions.question: A statutory close corporation may operate without:

options.B: A board of directors if shareholders manage directly

questions.explanation: Close corporations (small number of shareholders, stock transfer restrictions) may eliminate the board of directors and be managed directly by shareholders. They can also have more relaxed corporate formalities while maintaining liability protection.
questions.tip: Close corp: Can eliminate board. Shareholders manage directly. Relaxed formalities.

questions.question: After dissolution, partnership assets are distributed in what order?

options.B: Creditors first, then partners' capital, then profits
options.D: According to each partner's percentage interest

questions.explanation: Upon winding up, partnership assets are distributed: (1) outside creditors, (2) partners for advances/loans (partners as creditors), (3) partners' capital contributions, (4) remaining profits per profit-sharing ratios.
questions.tip: Winding up order: Outside creditors → partner loans → capital → profits.

questions.question: A merger between two corporations generally requires approval by:

options.B: Boards of directors and shareholders of both corporations

questions.explanation: Mergers typically require: (1) board approval of both corporations, (2) shareholder approval (usually majority) of both corporations, and (3) filing with the state. Dissenting shareholders may have appraisal rights.
questions.tip: Merger: Both boards approve + both shareholders vote + state filing. Dissenters get appraisal rights.

questions.question: Under modern LLC law, members' fiduciary duties to each other:

options.B: May be modified or eliminated by the operating agreement within limits
options.C: Are identical to corporate director duties

questions.explanation: LLC operating agreements can modify fiduciary duties, though most states prohibit eliminating the duty of loyalty entirely or acting in bad faith. This flexibility distinguishes LLCs from corporations and partnerships.
questions.tip: LLC fiduciary duties: Can be modified by operating agreement. Can't eliminate bad faith liability.

questions.question: A pre-incorporation stock subscription is:

options.B: Irrevocable for 6 months under the MBCA unless otherwise provided
options.C: Binding only after the corporation is formed

questions.explanation: Under MBCA, pre-incorporation subscriptions are irrevocable for 6 months unless the subscription agreement provides otherwise or all subscribers agree to revocation. This allows promoters to secure commitments before incorporation.
questions.tip: Pre-incorporation subscriptions: Irrevocable 6 months (MBCA) unless agreement says otherwise.

questions.question: A person who is not a partner but represents themselves as one may be liable as a partner under:

options.B: Partnership by estoppel, to those who rely on the representation

questions.explanation: Partnership by estoppel makes a person who represents themselves as a partner (or allows others to do so) liable to third parties who rely on that representation. This protects those who reasonably believe they're dealing with a partner.
questions.tip: Partnership by estoppel: Hold yourself out as partner = liable to those who rely on it.

questions.question: Appraisal rights allow dissenting shareholders to:

options.B: Receive the fair value of their shares from the corporation

questions.explanation: Appraisal rights (dissenters' rights) allow shareholders who object to certain fundamental changes (mergers, major asset sales) to demand the corporation purchase their shares at fair value. They cannot block the transaction.
questions.tip: Appraisal rights: Dissenter can demand fair value buyout. Can't stop the transaction.
